chapter.htmlHeader: How common is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Prevalence of multimorbidity is almost universal in older adults.
  • In a retrospective cohort study in England (n=403,985), the prevalence of multimorbidity was 27.2%.
    • Prevalence increased significantly with age.
    • Females had a higher prevalence of 30%, compared to 24.4% for males.
    • Amongst people with multimorbidity, 33.8% had both a physical and mental morbidity.
    • The majority of people with multimorbidity aged 18–24 years had physical–mental comorbidity (56.5%), compared with 23.7% of people aged 75–84 years.
    • The proportion of people with multimorbidity who had a physical–mental comorbidity increased substantially with greater socioeconomic deprivation.
  • In a Scottish study (n=1,751,841), the prevalence of multimorbidity was estimated to be 23.2%.
    • The prevalence of multimorbidity increased substantially with age — half of the people had at least one morbidity by age 50 years, and by age 65 years most were multimorbid.
    • However, more than half of people with multimorbidity and nearly two-thirds with physical–mental health comorbidity were younger than 65 years, and onset of multimorbidity occurred 10-15 years earlier in people in areas of socioeconomic deprivation.  
    • Socioeconomic deprivation was also associated with multimorbidity that included mental health disorders, and the prevalence of mental health disorders increased with the number of physical disorders.
  • For details of the most prevalent morbidities and their associated comorbidities, see Table 1.
